Introduction

Humans require 13 essential vitamins, classified as fat-soluble (A, D, E, K) or water-soluble (B complex [B1, B2, B3, B5, B6, B7, B9, B12], C).  Deficiencies can occur with any vitamin (eg, nutritional scarcity, malabsorption).  However, clinically significant toxicities are only seen with fat-soluble vitamins (especially A and D) because they accumulate in tissues and exert dose-dependent effects through nuclear transcription factors.  Water-soluble vitamins rarely cause toxicity because they are readily excreted in the urine.

General principles

All vitamins

In resource-rich regions, dietary deficiency is rare due to fortification of staple foods like grains and cereal.  In the resource-limited regions, several vitamin deficiencies (especially A, D, and B12) are endemic.  A vegan diet, which excludes all animal products, is associated with a greater risk of vitamin D and B12 deficiency (

).

Assuming adequate dietary availability:

  • Fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies are mainly associated with pancreatic insufficiency and cholestatic liver disease.
  • Water-soluble vitamin deficiencies are most commonly seen in chronic alcohol use disorder, due to impairment of intestinal transporters.
  • Combined fat- and water-soluble vitamin deficiency occurs in conditions that globally impair absorption, such as short bowel syndrome or Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 2
    ).

Deficiencies due to poor intake can be corrected with oral replacement and/or dietary changes.  In contrast, malabsorption and gastric bypass typically require parenteral (eg, intravenous or intramuscular) repletion.

B complex vitamins

The B complex vitamins (B1, B2, B3, B5, B6, B7 ,B9, B12) are grouped together because they are found in most foods and participate in numerous metabolic reactions as coenzymes.  There are 3 main mechanisms of deficiency:

  • Malabsorption:  B vitamin intestinal active transporters are located throughout the duodenum and proximal jejunum.  Malabsorption can be seen with chronic alcohol use disorder (eg, transporter downregulation), Roux-en-Y gastric bypass, or severe bowel inflammation (eg, Crohn disease).
  • Metabolic stress:  Due to the role of B vitamins in energy production (eg, TCA cycle), relative vitamin B deficiencies can develop during or after hypercatabolic states (eg, critical illness, trauma).  CYP450 inducers (eg, phenytoin, carbamazepine) can also increase vitamin B clearance, leading to deficiency.
  • Poor diet (rare):  B vitamins are found in a wide array of dietary sources (eg, whole grains, legumes, eggs, dairy, animal meat).  Therefore, dietary deficiency is rare, developing only in patients with severe malnutrition (eg, starvation) or a highly restricted "tea and toast" diet.

B vitamins are essential for energy production (eg, coenzymes for TCA cycle), so their deficiency affects metabolically active tissues such as the nervous system, skin, and mucosae.  Deficiency should be suspected in a malnourished patient with:

  • Neurological manifestations (eg, cognitive impairments, peripheral neuropathy, ataxia)
  • Mucositis (eg, glossitis, angular cheilitis, stomatitis)
  • Skin changes (eg, scaling, inflammation, seborrhea)

Individual B vitamin deficiencies are associated with specific variations and syndromes, as summarized in the following table (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 3
).  Important clinical entities include beriberi and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome (vitamin B1 deficiency), pellagra (vitamin B3 deficiency), and megaloblastic anemia (vitamin B9 and B12 deficiency).  This article discusses these syndromes in more detail below.

Fat-soluble vitamins

Vitamin A

Vitamin A includes retinol (active form) and carotenoids (provitamin, converted to retinol).  It is abundant in most foods, and especially in root vegetables (eg, carrots, sweet potatoes).  Vitamin A regulates retinal photoreceptor health (eg, synthesis of rhodopsin), epidermal differentiation (mucosae, skin, and cornea), general cellular immune function, and cerebrospinal fluid production (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 4
).

Deficiency occurs mainly in the setting of malabsorption (eg, pancreatic insufficiency, Roux-en-Y gastric bypass) or low dietary intake (eg, nutritionally poor settings).  Manifestations include night blindness (rod cell atrophy), xeroderma (rough, cracked skin), and xerophthalmia with potential corneal ulceration.  White, keratinized conjunctival plaques (Bitot spots) are characteristic.  Universal vitamin A supplementation is recommended for infants and children living in endemic regions, where it reduces blindness and mortality.  Vitamin A replacement is based on the manifestation:  higher doses for measles (to maintain mucosal integrity), intermediate doses for simple xeropthalmia, and lower doses in pregnant women (to avoid teratogenicity).

Toxicity occurs mainly in the setting of chronic exogenous retinoids (eg, acne treatment).  The major manifestation is pseudotumor cerebri (eg, headache, nausea, visual defects, optic disc edema) due to increased cerebrospinal fluid production.  Other effects include osteoporosis, hepatomegaly, and liver dysfunction.  Hypervitaminosis A in pregnant women can cause fetal defects due to inappropriate activation of homeobox (patterning) genes.  There is no specific treatment for vitamin A excess.

Vitamin D

Vitamin D includes:

  • D2 (ergocalciferol) from dietary sources (eg, dairy, fish oils)
  • D3 (cholecalciferol) synthesized by skin upon sunlight exposure

The liver converts both forms to 25-hydroxyvitamin D3 (calcifediol) for long-term storage.  The kidney subsequently converts this to 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D3 (calcitriol), the biologically active form (

image 1
).  Vitamin D stimulates intestinal calcium absorption (main function), renal calcium and phosphate resorption, and bone mineralization.

Insufficiency (eg, serum calcifediol 12-20 ng/mL) or deficiency (eg, <12 ng/mL) is due to low intake (eg, insufficient dairy), chronic kidney disease, decreased sun exposure, and malabsorption (eg, pancreatic insufficiency) (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 5
).  Multiple factors are usually involved.  Common manifestations include diffuse bone pain and tenderness, myopathy (eg, weakness due to hypocalcemia and hypophosphatemia), osteomalacia in adults, and rickets in children (
ðŸ“Š View Table: table 6
).  Nonskeletal manifestations include mood disturbances, fatigue, and depressed immunity (eg, frequent respiratory infections).  However, many patients remain asymptomatic even with marked deficiency.  Treatment generally adheres to the following framework:

  • Deficiency:  Initial loading with high dose D2 or D3 (eg, 50,000 IU/week x 8 weeks)
  • Insufficiency or maintenance:  Standard dose D2 or D3 (eg, 800-1,000 IU/day) indefinitely

Serum calcifediol level should be rechecked in 3-4 months to confirm target levels (ie, â‰¥20 ng/mL).  Concurrent calcium supplementation may be needed for hypocalcemia.  In fair-skinned patients, judicious sunlight exposure (eg, only enough to cause minimal erythema) generates the equivalent of 25,000 IU of oral vitamin D.

Toxicity is rare but can occur in the setting of massive overdose (eg, >100,000 IU/day) or ectopic production by macrophages in granulomatous disease (eg, sarcoidosis).  Manifestations are related to hypercalcemia (eg, constipation, neuropsychiatric changes, urinary stones).

Vitamin E

Vitamin E (tocopherols) is derived from dietary plant oils (eg, sunflower, wheat germ), nuts, and seeds.  Vitamin E is a fat-soluble antioxidant that protects lipids and cell membranes from free radical injury.

Deficiency is rare, but can be seen with malabsorption (eg, cholestatic liver disease) or genetic abetalipoproteinemia (inability to transport fatty acids).  Chronic manifestations include an increased risk of atherosclerosis and age-related macular degeneration, likely due to antioxidant consumption by inflammatory processes.  Other presentations include myopathy, peripheral neuropathy, spinocerebellar degeneration, and hemolytic anemia (due to red blood cell oxidative membrane damage) (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 7
).  Treatment involves repletion, typically with high doses of alpha-tocopherol polyethylene glycol, a PEGylated form of vitamin E that improves its solubility.There is no clinically significant toxicity.

Vitamin K

Vitamin K (phytonadione) is acquired mainly from green, leafy vegetables (eg, spinach, kale, broccoli) (

image 2
).  Vitamin K promotes normal blood coagulation.  It is required for gamma-carboxylation of several hemostatic factors:  II, VII, IX, X, proteins C and S (
ðŸ“Š View Table: table 8
).

Deficiency is primarily seen with malabsorption (eg, pancreatic insufficiency).  Broad-spectrum antibiotics can also deplete vitamin K2 (minor isoform) via disruption of the normal gut flora that  synthesize it, exacerbating deficiency.  Manifestations include coagulopathy, causing easy bruising, purpura, spontaneous gastrointestinal bleeding (eg, melena), and hemorrhagic disease of the newborn.Diagnosis of vitamin K deficiency is based mainly on the coagulation panel, because there is no readily available direct assay.  Prolongation of prothrombin time (PT/INR) is the earliest sign because factor VII has the shortest half-life.  As deficiency progresses, activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) may also prolong due to reduced activity of factors II, IX, and X.  For confirmation, some centers use des-gamma-carboxyprothrombin (an incompletely carboxylated form of factor II) as a surrogate marker.  Differentiating vitamin K deficiency from hepatic coagulopathy is a common clinical question in patients with cholestatic liver disease; factor V (non-vitamin K-dependent factor produced by the liver) is helpful because it remains normal in vitamin K deficiency but is decreased in liver failure.Treatment of severe coagulopathy usually involves a single 10-mg dose of parenteral vitamin K.  Intravenous administration carries a small risk of anaphylaxis (<0.05%).  Overcorrection of supratherapeutic INR, especially in patients on warfarin for high-risk conditions (eg, mechanical heart valves), can lead to thrombotic events.

Water soluble vitamins

Vitamin B1 (thiamine)

Vitamin B1 (thiamine) is a key cofactor for 2 enzymes of the tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle:

  • Pyruvate dehydrogenase complex (converts pyruvate to acetyl-CoA)
  • Alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase (converts alpha-ketoglutarate to succinyl-CoA).

Therefore, deficiency reflects TCA cycle disruption of the most energetically active tissue, such as neurons and cardiomyocytes.  As a result, clinical manifestations of thiamine deficiency are primarily neurologic (dry beriberi, Wernicke encephalopathy, Korsakoff syndrome) and cardiovascular (wet beriberi).  (Beriberi likely comes from the Sinhalese for "weakness".)

  • Dry beriberi is a symmetric polyneuropathy (motor and sensory) that presents with weakness, muscle atrophy, hyporeflexia, and gait ataxia.
  • Wernicke encephalopathy is an acute metabolic encephalopathy (eg, confusion, altered consciousness) often accompanied by ophthalmoplegia and cerebellar ataxia (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 9
    ).
  • Korsakoff syndrome is a chronic neuropsychiatric disorder that develops after Wernicke encephalopathy.  It is caused by metabolic infarction of the bilateral mamillary bodies and hippocampi (critical structures for memory).  Symptoms include anterograde amnesia (ie, unable to form new memories) and confabulation (creation of false memories to maintain a sense of continuity, without intention to deceive) (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 10
    ).
  • Wet beriberi is an acute dilated cardiomyopathy causing heart failure (eg, hypotension, edema, jugulovenous distension, S3 gallop).  A high-output heart failure state can be seen due to concomitant peripheral vasodilation (eg, thiamine also required to maintain vascular tone).

Treatment of severe thiamine deficiency involves parenteral (eg, intravenous, intramuscular) replacement because underlying absorption issues often limit oral efficacy.  In chronic alcohol use disorder, thiamine is usually given with other B complex vitamins, glucose, and electrolytes.  The "banana bag" (named because of its yellow color from riboflavin and folate) is a popular intravenous formulation used for this purpose.  Glucose (or carbohydrate) loading can precipitate Wernicke encephalopathy by increasing the metabolic demand for thiamine, depleting its remaining stores.  Therefore, thiamine is always given before or concurrently with glucose.  Neuropathy, encephalopathy, and cardiomyopathy are rapidly reversible if thiamine replacement is initiated early enough.

Vitamin B3 (niacin)

Vitamin B3 (niacin) is the precursor to nicotinamide nucleotides (eg, NAD+, NADP+), which are involved in many metabolic (eg, glycolysis, TCA cycle, oxidative phosphorylation) and redox (eg, glutathione regeneration) reactions.

Deficiency usually occurs in conjunction with other B complex vitamin deficiencies, as discussed previously.  The classic manifestation is pellagra ("rough skin"), consisting of "4 Ds" (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 11
):

  • Dermatitis (photosensitive rash):  due to the critical role of NADH in UV-induced DNA repair.  The characteristic rash involves blistering in sun-exposed areas (eg, nape and shoulders) that progresses to a hyperpigmented scale (
    image 3
    ).
  • Diarrhea (and vomiting):  due to GI mucosal inflammation, compounding B3 and other nutritional deficiencies.
  • Dementia (or delirium or psychosis) (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 11
    ):  due to dysfunction and apoptosis of neurons.
  • Death:  if left untreated, pellagra uniformly worsens, leading to coma and death.

Treatment of pellagra involves niacin repletion, usually as part of a multivitamin regimen with other B complex vitamins.  Niacin is well tolerated but can cause acute facial flushing in some patients.

Vitamins B9 (folate) and B12 (cobalamin)

Vitamin B9 (folate) and vitamin B12 (cobalamin) are abundant in dietary sources but differ in their absorption.

  • Cobalamin (B12) binds to intrinsic factor (IF) secreted by gastric parietal cells.  The B12-IF complex is absorbed in the ileum via receptor-mediated endocytosis.
  • Folate (B9) is absorbed in the jejunum without IF and converted to 5-methyl-tetrahydrofolate (5-methyl-THF) prior to entering the circulation.

Once absorbed, folate and B12 drive 3 major metabolic pathways:

  • Both vitamins enter the methionine cycle, which powers all methylation (1-carbon metabolism) reactions (
    figure 1
    ).  Folate (as 5-methyl-THF) donates a methyl group to homocysteine, converting it to methionine; vitamin B12 serves as a cofactor for this reaction.
  • Folate is a cofactor for the pyrimidine synthesis pathway (which methylates uracil to thymidine) necessary for DNA replication and repair (
    Methionine cycle
    ).
  • B12 is a cofactor for the methylmalonic acid (MMA) pathway, which converts methylmalonyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA to support the TCA cycle and myelin synthesis (
    figure 3
    ).

Folate and B12 deficiency can develop together or independently:

  • Combined folate and B12 deficiency is associated with poor dietary intake and malabsorption (eg, alcohol, gastric bypass).
  • Isolated folate deficiency is caused by drugs that inhibit dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR) (eg, methotrexate) (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 13
    ) or conditions that involve rapid cell proliferation (eg, pregnancy, chronic hemolysis, cancer).
  • Isolated B12 deficiency is typically caused by chronic atrophic gastritis (decreased parietal cell IF production), autoantibodies against IF (eg, pernicious anemia), or Diphyllobothrium (fish tapeworm).

Folate deficiency can develop over weeks because it is constantly consumed by the methionine cycle.  In contrast, B12 deficiency evolves over months to years because it serves as a coenzyme (ie, not consumed by the reaction it facilitates) and has a long half-life (eg, stored in liver).  Note:  vitamin B12 deficiency can cause a functional folate deficiency by preventing the regeneration of THF from 5-methyl-THF in the methionine cycle, thereby "trapping" folate in its inactive form.

Folate and B12 deficiencies share 2 clinical features in common:

  • Megaloblastic anemia:  Impaired DNA synthesis leads to large erythroid precursors; this megaloblastosis reflects these cells' inability to divide due to stalled nuclear replication despite continued cytoplasmic expansion (eg, intact protein synthesis).  The anemia leads to pallor, exertional dyspnea, and fatigue.  Peripheral blood shows macrocytosis (ie, mean corpuscular volume >100 Î¼m3) and hypersegmented neutrophils (ie, â‰¥6 nuclear lobes) due to repeated failed division (from low DNA content).
  • Elevated plasma homocysteine:  Both vitamins work together to convert homocysteine to methionine.  Elevated homocysteine is sometimes used as a proxy marker for deficiency.  It may promote atherogenesis and thrombosis, but not nearly to the same extent as primary (genetic) hyperhomocysteinemia (eg, cystathionine beta-synthase deficiency).

Unique manifestations of folate deficiency include:

  • Neural tube defects (NTDs):  Neurulation (organogenesis of brain and spinal cord) is the most DNA-intensive process of early gestation.  Folate deficiency can lead to NTDs including spina bifida, meningocele, and anencephaly.  In contrast, B12 affects postnatal myelination instead of prenatal development.

Unique manifestations of B12 deficiency include:

  • Methylmalonic acidemia:  B12 is required to convert methylmalonyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA.
  • CNS degeneration:  Longstanding B12 deficiency can cause demyelinating lesions of the spinal cord because buildup of MMA is directly toxic to oligodendrocytes.  The dorsal columns (proprioception, touch, and vibration) and lateral spinocortical tracts (motor function) are most severely affected.  This distinctive lesion pattern is referred to as subacute combined (ie, dorsal + lateral) degeneration.  Additional manifestations include cerebral dysfunction (eg, dementia, psychosis) and peripheral neuropathy.

Diagnosis of folate deficiency is based on hematologic findings (eg, macrocytic anemia) and low serum or erythrocyte folate levels.  Diagnosis of B12 deficiency is based on serum B12 levels.

  • Serum B12 <200 pg/mL indicates deficiency.
  • Serum B12 >300 pg/mL indicates sufficiency.
  • Serum B12 200-300 pg/mL is an equivocal result that requires further testing with MMA measurement (high MMA confirms deficiency).

Treatment involves repletion of folate and/or B12.  Folate therapy quickly resolves hematologic abnormalities but does not address ongoing neurologic damage from concurrent B12 deficiency (and may potentially delay the diagnosis).  Therefore, many clinicians provide simultaneous folate and B12 repletion for any patient with megaloblastic anemia.  Oral folate and intramuscular B12 are the standard modalities, but some variations exist, such as folinic acid (leucovorin) to "rescue" folate downstream of dihydrofolate reductase in patients receiving high dose inhibitors (eg, pemetrexed-based chemotherapy) (

image 4
).

Other B complex vitamins

  • Vitamin B2 (riboflavin) is the precursor to flavin nucleotides (eg, FMN, FAD), which serve as electron acceptors in the TCA cycle, electron transport chain, and fatty acid beta-oxidation.  It supports ATP production in a variety of tissues.  Manifestations are mainly limited to mucositis (eg, oral stomatitis, angular cheilitis, and glossitis).  Peripheral neuropathy, ocular keratitis, and seborrheic dermatitis are less common presentations.
  • Vitamin B5 (pantothenic acid) is the precursor for coenzyme A (CoA), which transfers acyl groups for many metabolic reactions in the TCA cycle and fatty acid oxidation.  Symptoms include peripheral neuropathy (eg, burning feet syndrome), cognitive impairment, and dermatitis.
  • Vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) serves as a cofactor for many enzymes involved in amino acid metabolism (eg, transaminases, decarboxylases), which supply gluconeogenesis and neurotransmitter synthesis.  It is also required for the initial step of heme synthesis (provision of aminolevulinic acid for porphyrin subunits).  Deficiency typically occurs in the setting of isoniazid treatment (eg, for tuberculosis), which inhibits conversion of B6 to its active form.  Manifestations include peripheral neuropathy, ataxia, mucositis (eg, cheilitis, stomatitis), and microcytic hypochromic anemia due to arrested heme production.
  • Vitamin B7 (biotin) is a cofactor for carboxylase enzymes involved in gluconeogenesis, branched-chain amino acid metabolism, and fatty acid synthesis (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 14
    ).  Deficiency is extremely rare.  Manifestations include peripheral neuropathy, myopathy, cognitive impairment, alopecia, and brittle nails.  Severe deficiency can lead to high anion-gap metabolic acidosis due to propionic acidemia (
    figure 4
    ).

Vitamin C (ascorbic acid)

Vitamin C (ascorbic acid) is a critical cofactor for prolyl and lysyl hydroxylases, which are required to produce, crosslink and stabilize collagen.  Deficiency occurs in the setting of multiple vitamin malabsorption (eg, chronic alcohol use), severe malnutrition, or limited intake of citrus fruits.

Severe vitamin C deficiency manifests with scurvy (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 15
).  Clinical features are related to collagen deficiency, and include petechiae, ecchymoses, perifollicular hemorrhages (
image 5
), gingival inflammation and bleeding ("spongy gums") (
image 6
), loose teeth, and poor wound healing or dehiscence.  Small "corkscrew" hairs are characteristic.  Arthralgia is common, reflecting cartilage degeneration and periosteal hemorrhages, and can progress to hemarthrosis.  Uncorrected, scurvy progresses to death from sepsis (bacterial translocation across weak basement membranes), intracranial or gastrointestinal bleeding, or acute aortic dissection.

Diagnosis is based on clinical features and low plasma vitamin C level.  Despite multiple hemorrhagic sites, coagulation studies and platelet count are normal.  The only hemostatic laboratory abnormality is a prolonged bleeding time (measures platelet activation at damaged vessel wall, which requires collagen).  Treatment involves vitamin C repletion, with improvement typically seen within several days.  Vitamin C is generally well tolerated, but can cause abdominal bloating, diarrhea, and calcium oxalate urinary stones in susceptible patients.

Summary

The essential vitamins required by humans are classified as fat-soluble (A, D, E, K) or water-soluble (B complex, C).

  • Fat-soluble vitamin deficiency typically develops with fat malabsorption (eg, pancreatic insufficiency, cholestatic liver disease).  Manifestations include night blindness and xerophthalmia (vitamin A), osteomalacia or rickets (vitamin D), hemolytic anemia and neurodegeneration (vitamin E), and coagulopathy (vitamin K).
  • The B complex vitamins include B1 (thiamine), B2 (riboflavin), B3 (niacin), B5 (panthothenic acid), B6 (pyridoxine), B7 (biotin), B9 (folate), and B12 (cobalamin).  Deficiency is typically due to severe malnutrition or malabsorption, especially in the setting of chronic alcohol overuse.  These vitamins serve as coenzymes for energy-producing reactions (eg, TCA cycle); therefore, metabolically active organs (eg, nervous system, heart, skin, mucosa) are most impacted by deficiency.  Distinct clinical presentations include beriberi and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome (thiamine), pellagra (niacin), and megaloblastic anemia with elevated homocysteine (folate and B12).

Although deficiency is possible with any vitamin, clinically significant toxicity is typically only seen with fat-soluble ones, especially vitamin A (pseudotumor cerebri, teratogenicity) and vitamin D (hypercalcemia).
